newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil shrs end down on re-election profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Brazil shrs end down on re-election profit-taking.

text.p: Brazilian shares closed sharply lower in moderate trade as investors reaped profits from several weeks of rises ahead of Tuesday's expected passage of a re-election bill by Congress' lower house, brokers said.
"It closed ugly," one broker told Reuters. "The only explanation is that the market has entered a profit-taking phase on the re-election vote, which was anticipated."
The Sao Paulo bourse's Bovespa index of 49 most-traded shares dropped 1.44 percent to close at 77,369 points in trade of 449.1 million reais ($429.8 million).

Brokers said broad profit-taking after the Chamber of Deputies granted prelimiary approval to a re-election amendment offset the generally upbeat prospects for local stocks and rises on Wall Street to drive prices down.

"There was no news and no surprise in Brasilia today and the Dow was rising, so investors apparently had very much anticipated re-election would pass," one dealer said. "It was really a wave of profit-taking." Blue chips across the board were hit. Benchmark Telebras preferred tumbled 1.66 percent to end at 88.60 reais while its voting common closed 1.65 percent lower at 82.70 reais.
Telebras shares and options accounted for a majority of the day's turnover.
Among top-losing leaders, state power holding Eletrobras
Eletrobras's decline led the drop in the bolsa's Electrical Energy Index of nine most-liquid shares, which ended off 1.6 percent at 2,251 points.
Leading power share Cemig also fell, ending off 2.07 percent at 42.99 reais.
State mining firm Cia Vale do Rio Doce closed 1.88 percent lower at 23.00 reais while Brazilian state oil monopoly Petrobras slipped 0.53 percent to end at 189.00 reais.

Bucking the tumbling trend, preferred shares of troubled meatpacker Chapeco skyrocketed 35.71 percent to 0.19 reais. "The company has had troubles for a while and the market speculated that the company has reached a deal with a large new partner," a broker sasid.
Brokers said profit-taking may continue Thursday at the open because the market closed in a selling mood.
